definitions.definition: to cut something into pieces with a sharp tool such as a knife
definitions.labels: (figurative)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(especially North American English)(British English)(British English)

examples.text: He was chopping logs for firewood.
Chop the carrots up into small pieces.
The country was chopped up into small administrative areas.
Chop the meat into small cubes.
I spent the day chopping up vegetables.
The furniture had been chopped to pieces.

definitions.definition: to suddenly stop providing or allowing something; to suddenly reduce something by a large amount
definitions.sensetop: be choppedbe chopped from something to something

examples.text: Their training courses are to be chopped.
The share price was chopped from 50 pence to 20 pence.
examples.contextForm: be chopped from something to something

definitions.definition: to hit somebody/something downwards with a quick, short movement

examples.text: Guzman tried to chop the ball on the ground and use his speed.

definitions.definition: to keep changing your mind or what you are doing

wordOrigin: verb late Middle English: variant of chap. chop and change. late Middle English (in the sense ‘barter, exchange’): perhaps related to Old English cēap ‘bargaining, trade’; compare with chap- in chapman, pedlar.
